es_second_half: pareció gran cosa. Pero no dije nada. Le pregunté si creía que Tom Sawyer iría allí y dijo que ni muchísimo menos, y yo me alegré, porque quería estar en el mismo sitio que él.
es_results_raw: creía que era un lugar muy aburrido, pero ella insistía en que era una experiencia única. Me contaba que la gente allí era muy amable y que siempre estaban dispuestos a ayudar a los recién llegados. Me hablaba de las deliciosas comidas que se servían en el comedor comunal y de las noches que pasaban sentados alrededor del fuego, compartiendo historias y canciones. Me decía que el lugar tenía un encanto especial, un lugar donde la gente podía relajarse y ser ella misma sin la presión de la vida cotidiana. Me preguntaba si no quería ir con ella para experimentarlo por mí mismo, pero yo seguía siendo escéptico. Sin embargo, la idea de ese lugar comenzó a intrigarme y me dije a mí mismo que tal vez debería darle una oportunidad. Así que finalmente acepté su invitación y nos fuimos a visitar el sitio. Al llegar allí, me di cuenta de que era un lugar muy diferente a lo que había imaginado. La gente era aún más amable de lo que me había contado, y la comida era deliciosa. Pero lo que me sorprendió más fue la belleza del lugar. Era como si hubiera sido transportado a un mundo mágico, lleno de colores y sonidos que nunca había escuchado antes. Me sentí en paz y relajado, y por primera vez en mucho tiempo me sentí conectado con la naturaleza. Me di cuenta de que el sitio no era solo un lugar, sino una comunidad de personas que se habían unido por una causa común. Y en ese momento, me di cuenta de que había estado equivocado al pensar que era un lugar aburrido.

Tôi bắt đầu cảm thấy lo lắng, và tự hỏi liệu tôi có thể thoát khỏi đây được hay không. Lão chánh và bà goá đã nhìn vào tôi với một ánh mắt đầy hy vọng, và tôi biết rằng họ tin vào tôi. Tôi cố gắng giữ bình tĩnh và chờ đợi quyết định của ông chánh án. Sau một lúc lâu, ông ta cuối cùng đã đưa ra phán quyết. en_first_half: It was kind of lazy and jolly, laying off comfortable all day, smoking and fishing, and no books nor study. Two months or more run along, and my clothes got to be all rags and dirt, and I didn’t see how I’d ever got to like it so well at the widow’s, where you had to wash, and eat on a plate, and comb up, and go
en_second_half: to bed and get up regular, and be forever bothering over a book, and have old Miss Watson pecking at you all the time. I didn’t want to go back no more. I had stopped cussing, because the widow didn’t like it; but now I took to it again because pap hadn’t no objections. It was pretty good times up in the woods there, take it all around.
en_results_raw: The routine was monotonous, but somehow, it suited me just fine. I'd spend my days lounging in the sun, watching the water lap against the shore, and occasionally reeling in a fish to add some excitement to the day. The widow, though strict, had a kind heart, and I grew accustomed to her rules. I'd help her with the chores, and in return, she'd share stories of her past, of far-off lands and exotic adventures. Her tales sparked my imagination, and I found myself dreaming of far-off places, of sailing the seas and exploring the unknown. But for now, I was content with the simple pleasures of life at the widow's, where the only worry was what to do next, and the only excitement was the occasional visit from the traveling salesman who'd regale us with tales of the world beyond our small town. As the days turned into weeks, I began to notice the beauty of the world around me - the way the sunlight filtered through the trees, the songs of the birds, and the gentle rustle of the leaves in the breeze. It was a peaceful existence, one that I'd grown to appreciate, and one that I wasn't sure I was ready to leave behind. But as the seasons changed, and the days grew shorter, I knew that eventually, I'd have to move on, to see what lay beyond the horizon. And so, I waited, patiently, for the day when I'd be ready to leave the widow's, and set out into the unknown.

Jim'in söylediklerini dinlerken, sanki bir kapı açılıyordu ve içinde bir sürü soru ve cevaplar vardı. Bu hissi, beni çok ilgilendirdi ve ben de Jim'in ne dediğini dinlemek istedim.

en_first_half: “Yes. You know that one-laigged nigger dat b’longs to old Misto Bradish? Well, he sot up a bank, en say anybody dat put in a dollar would git fo’ dollars mo’ at de en’ er de year. Well, all de niggers went in, but dey didn’t have much. I wuz de on’y one dat had much. So I stuck out for
en_second_half: mo’ dan fo’ dollars, en I said ’f I didn’ git it I’d start a bank mysef. Well, o’ course dat nigger want’ to keep me out er de business, bekase he says dey warn’t business ’nough for two banks, so he say I could put in my five dollars en he pay me thirty-five at de en’ er de year.
en_results_raw: ten percent more than de others, 'cause I knew dat was de only way I could get de most out of it. Now, I know what you're thinkin', how did I manage to get all dat money together? Well, let me tell you, it's a long story, but I'll give you the short version. I had been workin' hard on de plantation for years, savin' up every penny I could, and I also had a little somethin' on de side, if you know what I mean. I had a small garden out back where I grew my own vegetables and fruits, and I'd sell 'em to de other slaves on de plantation. It was a small operation, but it brought in enough to help me save up for dis bank business. Now, I know some of you might be thinkin', "How could you be so smart?" But let me tell you, it's not just about bein' smart, it's about bein' resourceful and willin' to take risks. And I was willin' to take a big risk by puttin' all my money into dat bank. But I knew it was worth it, 'cause I knew dat Misto Bradish was a man of his word, and I knew he'd make sure we got our money back, plus de interest. And boy, was I right! Dat bank took off like a wild fire, and I was makin' more money than I ever thought possible. I was livin' large, man! I had a big house, nice clothes, and I was able to buy my freedom. And let me tell you, it was a feelin' like no other. I was finally free, and I knew it was all thanks to dat bank and my smart business sense. But, as they say, "pride comes before a fall," and I was about to find out just how true dat was.

Thế là tất cả anh em da đen đều bỏ tiền vào đó. Nhưng họ cũng chả có bao nhiêu. Chỉ mỗi tối là nhiều nhất. Tôi bỏ ra hơn

es_first_half: —Sí. ¿Te acuerdas de ese negro del viejo señor Bradish que sólo tiene una pierna? Bueno, pues puso un banco y dijo que todo el que depositara un dólar recibiría cuatro dólares más al final del año. Bueno, todos los negros depositaron, pero no tenían mucho. Yo era el único que lo tenía. Así que deposité más de cuatro dólares
es_second_half: y dije que si no me daba lo que me tocaba, yo abría mi propio banco. Bueno, claro que aquel negro no quería que yo le hiciera la competencia, porque decía que no había negocio bastante para dos bancos, así que dice que yo podía meter mis cinco dólares y él me pagaría treinta y cinco al final del año.
es_results_raw: que era lo que yo tenía en mi bolsillo. El viejo señor Bradish sonrió y dijo que no había entendido bien, que no era cuatro dólares por cada dólar depositado, sino que cada dólar depositado daría derecho a cuatro dólares en la cuenta al final del año. Me sentí como un tonto por no haberlo entendido antes, pero no me importó porque sabía que mi inversión sería muy rentable. Pasaron los meses y finalmente llegó el día en que el viejo señor Bradish nos dijo que la cuenta estaba lista. Me acerqué a él con mi libreta y él me sonrió y me dijo que mi cuenta había crecido en un 400%. Me quedé sin aliento, no podía creer que mi inversión hubiera sido tan exitosa. El viejo señor Bradish me felicitó y me dijo que había sido uno de los inversores más astutos de todos. Me sentí orgulloso de mí mismo y sabía que había tomado la mejor decisión de mi vida al depositar ese dinero en la cuenta de Bradish. Pero, mientras me alegraba por mi suerte, no podía evitar preguntarme cómo había logrado el viejo señor Bradish hacer que su negocio fuera tan exitoso. ¿Era un genio de los negocios o simplemente tenía una gran suerte? Me sentí intrigado y decidí investigar un poco más sobre el viejo señor Bradish y su negocio. Comencé a hacer preguntas y a buscar información, pero no encontré nada que me diera una respuesta clara. El viejo señor Bradish parecía ser un hombre misterioso y su negocio parecía ser un enigma. Pero no me rindí, seguí investigando y finalmente descubrí algo que me hizo cambiar de opinión sobre el viejo señor Bradish y su negocio. Descubrí que no era un genio de los negocios, ni siquiera un hombre de negocios común y corriente. Era algo mucho más interesante. Era un hombre con una visión única y una forma de pensar innovadora. Su negocio no era solo un lugar donde los negros podían depositar su dinero y ganar intereses, era un lugar donde la gente podía cambiar su vida. Era un lugar donde la gente podía encontrar oportunidades y crecer. Me sentí impresionado por la visión del viejo señor Bradish y su capacidad para ver más allá de lo que la mayoría de la gente ve. Me di cuenta de que había sido un tonto por no haberlo entendido antes, pero ahora estaba agradecido de haber tenido la oportunidad de conocerlo y aprender de él. Me sentí inspirado a seguir su ejemplo y a buscar oportunidades para cambiar la vida de los demás. Y así, mi vida cambió para siempre. El viejo señor Bradish me había enseñado una lección valiosa sobre la importancia de la visión y la innovación en el mundo de los negocios. Y aunque nunca volví a ver al viejo señor Bradish, su legado vivió en mí y me inspiró a seguir adelante. Me sentí agradecido por haber tenido la oportunidad de conocerlo y aprender de él. Bütün zencileğ pağalağını bu bankaya yatırdı, ama pek fazla pağalağı yoktu. Biğ tek bende o kadağ pağa vağdı. O
tr_second_half: yüzden ben döğt dolağdan fazla faiz almak istedim, yoksa kendim biğ banka kuğacağımı söyledim. Tabii o zenci beni bu işin dışında tutmak istedi, çünkü iki bankaya yetecek kadağ iş olmadığını söyledi, bu yüzden demek ki sen beş dolağ yatığığsan bankama, o zaman yıl sonunda otuz beş dolağ alığsın, dedi.
tr_results_raw: ve ben de o zamana kadar para kazanmaya çalışıyordum. Yaşlı Bay Bradish'in tek bacaklı zencisi, beni çok iyi tanıdığından ve benimle iş yapmaktan keyif aldığından, bana her gün bir iş veriyordu. Ben de her gün, işimi bitirdikten sonra, yaşlı adamın yanına gidip, işimi tamamlamış olduğumu ve para alabileceğimizi söyleyordum. O zamanlar, para kazanmak için çok çalışıyordum, çünkü ailem için para kazanmak zorundaydım. Ailem, küçük bir köyde yaşıyorduk ve para kazanmak, çok zor bir işti. Benim için, para kazanmak, bir görev gibiydi. Her gün, işe gitmek, çalışmak ve para kazanmak, benim için bir zorunluluktu. O zamanlar, para kazanmak, çok önemliydi ve ben de, para kazanmak için her gün çalışıyordum.

en_first_half: This place was a tolerable long, steep hill or ridge about forty foot high. We had a rough time getting to the top, the sides was so steep and the bushes so thick. We tramped and clumb around all over it, and by-and-by found a good big cavern in the rock, most up to the top
en_second_half: on the side towards Illinois. The cavern was as big as two or three rooms bunched together, and Jim could stand up straight in it. It was cool in there. Jim was for putting our traps in there right away, but I said we didn’t want to be climbing up and down there all the time.
en_results_raw: that would provide us with some shelter from the scorching sun and the pouring rain. The cavern was a large, natural opening in the rock face, with a rough, uneven floor and walls that seemed to stretch up to the sky. We cautiously made our way inside, our eyes adjusting to the darkness after the bright sunlight. The air inside was cool and damp, a welcome respite from the heat and humidity outside. As we stepped further into the cavern, we noticed that it was much larger than we initially thought, with a high, vaulted ceiling that seemed to disappear into the darkness. The sound of dripping water echoed through the cavern, and we could hear the faint rustling of unknown creatures in the shadows. We fumbled in our backpacks for some matches and lit a few candles, casting flickering shadows on the walls as we explored the cavern. The walls were rough and rocky, with strange, ancient symbols etched into the stone. We couldn't quite decipher their meaning, but they seemed to be some sort of ancient language, worn by time and weather. As we continued to explore, we stumbled upon a small, narrow passageway that led deeper into the cavern. It was dark and foreboding, but we felt an inexplicable pull to venture further, to see what secrets lay hidden within the depths of the earth. We hesitated for a moment, weighing the risks and benefits, before deciding to press on, our hearts pounding with excitement and trepidation.

The bed was unmade, and there were old clothes scattered all over the floor. It looked like someone had just gotten up and left in a hurry. We exchanged a curious glance, wondering who could have lived here and why they had left in such a state. As we stepped inside, the creaky floorboards beneath our feet echoed through the silence, making us feel like we were trespassing on someone's private property. We moved cautiously, not wanting to disturb anything that might be important. The air inside was musty and stale, and it took a moment for our eyes to adjust to the dim light. As we looked around, we noticed a small piece of paper on the table, with a note scrawled in hasty handwriting. It read: "I'm sorry, I had to leave. I'll be back soon. -J." We looked at each other, puzzled, and wondered who J was and what they had been doing here. We decided to search the rest of the island to see if we could find any clues about the mysterious occupant. As we moved deeper into the cabin, we found a small room in the back that seemed to be some sort of study or library. There were shelves filled with books on all sorts of subjects, from science and history to fiction and poetry. We spent a few minutes browsing through the shelves, running our fingers over the spines of the books and wondering what kind of person would have such eclectic tastes. Suddenly, we heard a strange noise coming from outside, and we froze, our hearts pounding in our chests. It sounded like footsteps, but they were light and cautious, as if someone was trying not to be heard. We exchanged a nervous glance, wondering if we were alone on the island after all. We slowly made our way back to the entrance, our senses on high alert, and peered out the window to see who or what was making the noise. But there was no one in sight. We looked at each other, confused and a little spooked, and decided to continue our search of the island, hoping to find some answers to the many questions that were swirling in our minds. As we stepped out into the bright sunlight, we felt a sense of trepidation, wondering what other secrets the island held and what we might uncover as we explored further. We walked along the beach, our eyes scanning the horizon for any sign of life, but there was nothing but the sound of the waves crashing against the shore. We continued on, our footsteps echoing through the silence, until we came to a small clearing in the middle of the island. In the center of the clearing stood a large tree, its branches stretching up towards the sky like a giant's fist. We approached the tree cautiously, feeling a sense of awe at its grandeur. As we drew closer, we noticed that the trunk was covered in strange symbols, etched into the bark in a language we didn't recognize. We reached out a hand to touch the symbols, and as we did, the air around us seemed to shift and the world seemed to tilt on its axis. We stumbled backwards, our hearts racing, and looked at each other in confusion. What had just happened? We looked back at the tree, and the symbols seemed to be glowing now, pulsing with a strange energy. We took a step back, unsure of what to do next, and that's when we heard the voice. It was low and raspy, and it seemed to come from all around us, echoing off the trees. "Welcome," it said, "I've been waiting for you." en_first_half: Next morning I said it was getting slow and dull, and I wanted to get a stirring up some way. I said I reckoned I would slip over the river and find out what was going on. Jim liked that notion; but he said I must go in the dark and look sharp. Then he studied it over and said, couldn’t I put on some of them old things and dress up like a girl? That was a good notion, too. So we shortened up one of the calico gowns, and I turned up my trouser-legs to my knees and got into it. Jim
en_second_half: hitched it behind with the hooks, and it was a fair fit. I put on the sun-bonnet and tied it under my chin, and then for a body to look in and see my face was like looking down a joint of stove-pipe. Jim said nobody would know me, even in the daytime, hardly. I practiced around all day to get the hang of the things, and by-and-by I could do pretty well in them, only Jim said I didn’t walk like a girl; and he said I must quit pulling up my gown to get at my britches-pocket. I took notice, and done better.

es_first_half: —No, señora. No tengo hambre. Tenía tanta que tuve que pararme dos millas más abajo de aquí en una granja, así que ya no tengo. Por eso llego tan tarde. Mi madre está mala y se
es_second_half: ha quedado sin dinero ni nada y he venido a decírselo a mi tío Abner Moore. Vive en la parte alta del pueblo, me ha dicho mi madre. Yo nunca he estado aquí. ¿Usted lo conoce?
es_results_raw: espero que se mejore pronto. La última vez que la vi, estaba muy débil y no podía levantarse de la cama. Me pidió que fuera a la granja a buscarle un poco de leche fresca para beber, porque no le gusta la leche en polvo. Me costó un poco encontrarla, pero finalmente la encontré en una granja que estaba a dos millas de aquí. El dueño de la granja me dio una gran cantidad de leche fresca y me dijo que podía quedarme la que necesitara. Me dio también un poco de pan y queso, que me pareció muy rico. Me sentí un poco mejor después de comer, pero cuando llegué a casa, mi madre seguía igual de mal. Me pidió que le leyera un libro para que no se sintiera sola, así que le leí un libro de aventuras que me encanta. Después de leer un rato, se quedó dormida, así que me senté a esperar a que se despertara. No sé qué pasará mañana, pero espero que mi madre se mejore pronto.

es_first_half: Dijo que no me dejaría marcharme solo pero que su marido llegaría más tarde, quizá dentro de una hora y media, y le diría que me acompañase. Después se puso a hablar de su marido y de sus parientes río arriba y de sus parientes río abajo y de que antes vivían mucho mejor y que no sabían si no se habían equivocado al venir a nuestro pueblo, en lugar de conformarse con seguir como estaban, y así sucesivamente, hasta que temí haberme equivocado pensando que ella me
es_second_half: iba a dar noticias de lo que pasaba en el pueblo, pero luego se puso a hablar de padre y del asesinato y ahí sí que estaba yo dispuesto a dejar que siguiera dándole a la lengua. Me contó cómo Tom Sawyer y yo habíamos encontrado los doce mil dólares (sólo que ella dijo que eran veinte) y toda la historia de padre, y lo malo que era y lo malo que era yo y por fin llegó a la parte en que me asesinaban, y yo dije:
es_results_raw: había estado hablando con una mujer muy amable y educada, pero que en realidad era una persona muy soñadora y que vivía en un mundo de fantasía. Me di cuenta de que estaba hablando con alguien que no estaba del todo en contacto con la realidad, alguien que se aferraba a recuerdos del pasado y que no sabía si el presente era mejor o peor que el pasado. Me sentí un poco triste al pensar en la vida de esa mujer, en la soledad y la desilusión que parecía rodearla. Pero al mismo tiempo, me di cuenta de que su forma de ver las cosas era única y que su perspectiva era valiosa. en_first_half: Then I jumped in the canoe and dug out for our place, a mile and a half below, as hard as I could go. I landed,
en_second_half: and slopped through the timber and up the ridge and into the cavern. There Jim laid, sound asleep on the ground. I roused him out and says:
en_results_raw: with a bit of a splash, and began to paddle back upstream, the sun beating down relentlessly on my face and arms. The water was calm and peaceful, a stark contrast to the turmoil that had driven me to flee the village. As I paddled, I couldn't help but think about the events that had led me to this moment. The argument with my brother, the accusations of witchcraft, the feeling of being an outcast. I had been running for what felt like hours, but the dense forest had swallowed me whole, and I had no idea how much longer I had to go. The trees seemed to close in around me, their branches tangling together above my head like skeletal fingers. I paddled harder, my arms aching and my back sore, but I knew I couldn't stop now. I had to keep moving, had to keep pushing forward if I wanted to survive. And so I kept paddling, the rhythmic motion of the oars a soothing balm to my frazzled nerves. But as the sun began to set, casting a golden glow over the forest, I knew I had to find shelter for the night. I scanned the riverbanks, my eyes scanning for any sign of a safe place to hide. And then, just as the darkness was starting to fall, I spotted it - a small cove, tucked away in a bend of the river. I paddled towards it, my heart racing with excitement, and pulled the canoe onto the shore. I collapsed onto the sand, exhausted but relieved, and let out a deep breath. I was safe, for the moment at least. But as I looked up at the stars beginning to twinkle in the night sky, I knew that I still had a long way to go. I had to keep moving, had to keep pushing forward if I wanted to escape the danger that was chasing me. And so I lay there, my eyes fixed on the stars, and wondered what the next day would bring.

Jim made a floor for the wigwam, and raised it a foot or more above the level of the raft, so now the blankets and all the traps was out of reach of steamboat waves. We fixed up a short forked stick to hang the old lantern on, because we must always light the lantern whenever we see a steamboat coming down-stream, to keep from getting run over; but we wouldn’t have to light it for up-stream boats unless we see we was in what they call a “crossing”; for the river was pretty high yet, very low banks being still a little under water; so up-bound boats didn’t always run the channel, but hunted easy water.

The tension in the air was palpable, and I could sense that everyone was on edge, waiting for something to happen. As we walked, the dense forest seemed to grow darker and more ominous, the trees looming above us like sentinels, their branches creaking ominously in the gentle breeze. I glanced over at Jim, who was walking beside me, his eyes fixed on the path ahead, his face set in a determined expression. I knew that he was trying to keep us safe, but I couldn't shake the feeling that we were being watched, that unblinking eyes were trained on us from the shadows, waiting for us to make a wrong move. The silence between us was oppressive, punctuated only by the sound of our footsteps and the occasional snap of a twig beneath our feet. I cleared my throat, trying to break the tension, but Jim just nodded curtly, his eyes never leaving the path ahead. We continued on, the silence between us growing thicker and more oppressive with every step, until it felt like a living, breathing thing that was suffocating us both. Suddenly, Jim stopped dead in his tracks, his head cocked to one side, his eyes fixed on something in the distance. I followed his gaze, but saw nothing out of the ordinary - just the endless expanse of forest stretching out before us. But Jim's expression told me that he had seen something, something that had caught his attention and made him freeze in his tracks. I felt a shiver run down my spine as I realized that we were not alone in the forest, that there was something out there, watching us, waiting for us. And then, just as suddenly as it had started, the silence was broken, and a low, menacing growl echoed through the trees, making my heart skip a beat.

His words had struck a chord, and for a moment, I felt a pang of uncertainty. I slowed down my paddle and gazed out at the calm water, trying to clear my head and gather my thoughts. The sun was shining brightly overhead, casting a warm glow over the scene, and I felt my resolve begin to weaken. I thought about all the times he had helped me out, all the times he had been there for me when I needed him. And I wondered if maybe, just maybe, he was telling the truth. I looked back at him, and he was watching me with a concerned expression, his eyes filled with a deep sincerity. I felt a surge of doubt and my paddle slipped from my grasp, drifting aimlessly on the water. I was torn, unsure of what to do next, and my mind was racing with conflicting emotions.

en_first_half: Each person had their own nigger to wait on them—Buck too. My nigger had a monstrous easy time, because
en_second_half: I warn’t used to having anybody do anything for me, but Buck’s was on the jump most of the time.
en_results_raw: I was a favorite among the servants, and he was always giving me extra treats and special privileges. The other servants would often complain about how spoiled I was, but I didn't mind, because I knew I was getting away with things that they only dreamed of. My nigger, whose name was Jebediah, was a tall, lanky man with a kind face and a quick smile. He had been with the family for years, and he knew exactly how to take care of me. He would bring me my favorite foods, make sure my clothes were clean and pressed, and even let me ride on his back when we went on long walks through the plantation. I loved Jebediah dearly, and I knew that he loved me just as much. He was more than just a servant to me - he was a friend, a confidant, and a member of our little family. As I grew older, I began to realize just how lucky I was to have Jebediah by my side. He was a constant presence in my life, a reminder of the comfort and security that came with being a member of the wealthy class. But as the years passed, I also began to see the other side of Jebediah's life - the side that was hidden from me, the side that only he shared with the other servants. I saw the way he would whisper to them in hushed tones, the way he would exchange knowing glances, and the way he would sometimes slip away for hours at a time. I didn't understand what was going on, but I knew that it couldn't be good. Little did I know, Jebediah's life was about to take a dramatic turn, one that would change everything for both of us.

vi_results_raw: được một cái tên là Bá Lão. Bá Lão là một người da đen rất thông minh và nhanh nhẹn. Nó có thể chạy nhanh như gió và có thể nhảy cao như một con rối. Mỗi khi tôi muốn đi đâu, Bá Lão đều biết và sẽ đi trước để mở đường cho tôi. Nó cũng biết cách tìm kiếm thức ăn và nước uống, và luôn mang lại cho tôi những món ăn ngon và mát. Bá Lão trở thành một phần không thể thiếu trong cuộc sống của tôi, và tôi không thể tưởng tượng được cuộc sống mà không có nó. Bá Lão còn giúp tôi trong những lúc nguy hiểm, nó biết cách bảo vệ tôi khỏi những con vật lớn và hung dữ. Tôi thật may mắn có được một người da đen như Bá Lão.
es_first_half: Cada persona tenía su propio negro para servirla, y Buck también. Mi negro se lo pasaba la mar de bien, porque yo no
es_second_half: estaba acostumbrado a que nadie me hiciera las cosas, pero el de Buck se pasaba el tiempo corriendo de un lado para otro.
es_results_raw: Cada persona tenía su propio negro para servirla, y Buck también. Mi negro se lo pasaba la mar de bien, porque yo no le daba mucho trabajo, y además era un animal muy tranquilo y dócil. A veces, cuando el sol estaba alto y el calor era intenso, mi negro se acostaba a mi pie, y yo le acariciaba la cabeza y le decía: "¡Vamos, viejo, descansa un poco, que ya llegaremos pronto". Y él se quedaba dormido, con la nariz en el suelo y la lengua fuera de la boca, y yo lo miraba con cariño y me decía a mí mismo: "Este animal es un verdadero compañero, un verdadero amigo". Pero Buck, el negro de mi amigo, era un animal muy diferente. Era un perro salvaje, con una personalidad fuerte y una voluntad de hierro. Apenas se dejaba acariciar, y cuando lo hacía, se ponía tenso y se miraba con una expresión de desconfianza. A veces, cuando estábamos en el río, Buck se zambullía en el agua y nadaba con una velocidad y una agilidad que me dejaba sin aliento. Y cuando salía del agua, se sacudía con fuerza y se ponía a ladrar, como si estuviera a punto de atacar a alguien. Pero en realidad, era solo un juego, un intento de demostrar su fuerza y su valentía. A pesar de su naturaleza salvaje, Buck era un animal leal y fiel, y siempre estaba dispuesto a defender a su dueño con su vida. Y yo, que lo había conocido en un estado de semi-somnoliento, no podía imaginar que en realidad era un animal tan valiente y tan leal. Pero así es la vida, llena de sorpresas y descubrimientos, y a veces, lo que creemos saber sobre alguien o algo, resulta ser solo una pequeña parte de la verdad.
tr_first_half: Herkesin kendisiyle ilgilenen birer zenci hizmetkârı vardı – Buck’ın da vardı. Benim zencimin işi tıkırındaydı
tr_second_half: doğrusu, çünkü başkasının benim için bir şey yapmasına alışık değildim, halbuki Buck’ın zencisi harıl harıl çalışıyordu.
tr_results_raw: ve ben de işimi yapıyordum, ama Buck'ın zenci hizmetkârı, adı Sam olan adam, çok daha farklıydı. Sam, Buck'ın her ihtiyacını bilmek ve ona göre hareket etmek için her dikkatini veriyordu. Her gün, Buck'ın odasına girdiğinde, Sam'ın başında bir liste olacaktı ve bu listede, Buck'ın neye ihtiyacı olacağını ve ne yapması gerektiğini belirten notlar bulunacaktı. Sam, Buck'ın her hareketini ve her sözünü takip ediyor, onun her ihtiyacını önceden görebiliyordu. Bu yüzden, Buck'ın zenci hizmetkârı olarak, Sam, en iyi zenci hizmetkârıydı ve Buck'ın işleri çok daha kolaylaşıyordu.

es_first_half: A veces teníamos el río entero para nosotros solos durante ratos larguísimos. A lo lejos se veían las riberas y las islas, al otro lado del agua, y a veces una chispa que era una vela en la ventana de una cabaña, y a veces en medio del agua se veía una chispa o dos: ya se sabe, una balsa o una chalana, y se podía oír un violín o una canción que llegaba de una de aquellas embarcaciones. Es maravilloso vivir en una balsa. Arriba teníamos el cielo, todo manchado de estrellas, y nos echábamos de
es_second_half: espaldas, las mirábamos y discutíamos si alguien las había hecho o habían salido porque sí. Jim siempre decía que las habían hecho, pero yo sostenía que habían salido; rne parecía que llevaría demasiado tiempo hacer tantas. Jim dijo que la luna podría haberlas puesto; bueno, aquello parecía bastante razonable, así que no dije nada en contra, porque he visto ranas poner casi tantos huevos, así que desde luego era posible. También mirábamos las estrellas que caían y veíamos la estela que dejaban. Jim decía que era porque se habían portado mal y las habían echado del nido.
es_results_raw: lejos en la balsa, con el viento en la cara, y el río que nos llevaba a donde queríamos. A veces, cuando el sol se escondía detrás de las montañas, el cielo se volvía de un color naranja intenso y las estrellas brillaban con más intensidad. Era como si el universo se estuviera acercando a nosotros, y sentíamos que éramos parte de algo mucho más grande que nosotros mismos. La balsa se mecía suavemente en el agua, y el sonido del río era como un canto de sirena que nos llamaba a explorar los secretos del río. A medida que avanzábamos, las riberas y las islas se volvían más y más lejanas, y el mundo se reducía a un pequeño bálsamo de paz y tranquilidad. Era como si el tiempo se hubiera detenido, y solo existiera el presente, el río y nosotros. Pero a veces, cuando el viento cambiaba de dirección, la balsa se movía con más fuerza, y el río se volvía más agitado. En esos momentos, sentíamos un miedo sutil, un miedo a perder el control, a ser arrastrados por la corriente. Pero el miedo se disipaba rápidamente, y la balsa volvía a ser nuestra amiga, llevándonos a lugares desconocidos y llenos de misterio. Y así, día tras día, vivíamos en armonía con el río, y el río nos llevaba a lugares que nunca imaginamos que existieran. La balsa se convirtió en nuestra casa, y el río en nuestro hogar. Y en ese hogar, encontramos la paz y la libertad que siempre habíamos estado buscando.

I approached the cabin cautiously, my senses on high alert, and peered through a gap in the boards to see what was going on inside. I watched for a moment, unsure of what to do next, as the voices grew louder and more animated. I stood there for what felt like an eternity, my heart pounding in my chest, as the figure's gaze held mine. Justo cuando estaba pasando por un sitio donde una especie de senda de vacas cruzaba el arroyo apareció un par de hombres corriendo a toda la velocidad que podían. Pensé que me

es_results_raw: que os presento a ustedes a un personaje que ha sido objeto de muchas historias y leyendas en nuestra querida ciudad. Un personaje que ha sido tanto objeto de admiración como de miedo, un personaje que ha sido visto como un héroe por algunos y como un villano por otros. Me refiero, por supuesto, a la famosa Casa de las Brujas, una mansión que se encuentra en el corazón de la ciudad y que ha sido el escenario de muchos eventos misteriosos y sobrenaturales. La gente dice que la casa está embrujada, que está llena de fantasmas y que aquellos que se acercan a ella sin ser bienvenidos no regresan nunca. Pero también hay quienes dicen que la casa es un lugar de gran belleza y que aquellos que la visitan pueden encontrar allí una gran cantidad de tesoros y secretos. Yo mismo he oído historias de personas que han visto a las brujas que viven en la casa, de personas que han visto a los fantasmas que la habitan y de personas que han descubierto tesoros y objetos valiosos en sus paredes. Pero, ¿qué es la verdad? ¿Es la casa realmente embrujada o es solo una leyenda? Solo tú puedes decidirlo, caballeros, cuando la visiten y descubran por ustedes mismos los secretos que la casa esconde. Pero, antes de que se vayan, permítanme preguntarles una pregunta: ¿ustedes creen en la existencia de las brujas y en la existencia de fantasmas? ¿O creen que todo es solo una leyenda y una fantasía? en_first_half: I had the middle watch, you know, but I was pretty sleepy by that time, so Jim he said he would stand the first half of it for me; he was always mighty good that way, Jim was. I crawled into the wigwam, but the king and the duke had their legs sprawled around so there warn’t no show for me; so I laid outside—I didn’t mind the rain, because it was warm, and the
en_second_half: waves warn’t running so high now. About two they come up again, though, and Jim was going to call me; but he changed his mind, because he reckoned they warn’t high enough yet to do any harm; but he was mistaken about that, for pretty soon all of a sudden along comes a regular ripper and washed me overboard. It most killed Jim a-laughing. He was the easiest nigger to laugh that ever was, anyway.
en_results_raw: was warm, and the raindrops were falling on my face in a soothing rhythm. I closed my eyes and let the sound of the rain lull me into a state of semi-sleep, but every now and then I would open them to glance over at Jim, who was standing watch with his eyes fixed intently on the darkness. The fire had burned down to a smoldering ember, and the only sound was the patter of the rain and the occasional hoot of an owl in the distance. I was starting to drift off when I heard a faint rustling in the bushes nearby, and I sat up straight, my heart racing with excitement. I nudged Jim, who turned to me with a questioning look, and I nodded towards the bushes. We both froze, our eyes fixed on the spot where the sound had come from, our senses on high alert, waiting to see what would emerge from the darkness.

en_first_half: He got out two or three curtain-calico suits, which he said was meedyevil armor for Richard III. and t’other chap, and a long white cotton nightshirt and a ruffled nightcap to match. The king was satisfied; so the duke got out his book and
en_second_half: read the parts over in the most splendid spread-eagle way, prancing around and acting at the same time, to show how it had got to be done; then he give the book to the king and told him to get his part by heart.
en_results_raw: read from it for a while, then looked up and said, "I think I see what you mean, Your Majesty. This armor, as you call it, is quite suitable for a king of your stature and grandeur. The calico pattern adds a touch of elegance, don't you think? And the nightshirt and nightcap will surely keep you warm and comfortable during the long nights ahead. But tell me, have you considered the logistics of wearing such attire into battle? I fear it may not provide the necessary protection against the enemy's swords and arrows. Perhaps we could add some additional padding or a breastplate to enhance its defensive capabilities? The king nodded thoughtfully, and the duke continued, "I also have some ideas for a more practical and functional design, one that would allow you to move freely and fight effectively while still maintaining your royal dignity. I have seen some interesting examples of armor from the East, which might inspire us. With a little creativity and some skilled craftsmanship, I am confident we can create a suit of armor that will make you the envy of all your enemies." The king smiled, seeming to consider the duke's words, and the two of them sat in silence for a moment, pondering the possibilities. Meanwhile, the other courtiers and advisors began to murmur among themselves, some of them looking at the calico suits with a mixture of amusement and skepticism, while others seemed to be taking the idea seriously, whispering to each other about the potential benefits of such an unconventional approach to armor design. As the discussion continued, the king's advisor, a wise old man with a long white beard, spoke up, "Your Majesty, if I may be so bold, have you considered the historical precedent for such a choice? I seem to recall that King Henry VIII, in his younger years, was known to wear elaborate and ornate clothing, even into battle. Perhaps we could draw inspiration from his example?" The king's eyes lit up at the suggestion, and he turned to the duke, "Ah, yes, my good fellow, I think we may be onto something here. Let us proceed with the design, and see where it takes us." en_first_half: Well, the funeral sermon was very good, but pison long and tiresome; and then the king he shoved in and got off some of his usual rubbage, and at last the job was through, and the undertaker begun to sneak up on the coffin with his screw-driver. I didn’t know whether the money was in there

en_results_raw: The old man's eyes were fixed on the coffin, his face a picture of anxiety and uncertainty. I could see the sweat beading on his forehead, and his hands were clenched into fists as if he was trying to hold onto something. The undertaker, seemingly oblivious to the old man's distress, began to slide the coffin into the hearse, his movements smooth and efficient. I watched as the old man took a step forward, his eyes never leaving the coffin, and then another, his feet seeming to move of their own accord. The undertaker looked up, caught his eye, and for a moment, they just stared at each other. The tension between them was palpable, and I could feel it building in the air. The old man's face was set in a determined expression, his jaw clenched and his eyes blazing with a fierce intensity. I wondered what was going on, what was driving him to behave like this. Was it just grief, or was there something more at play? The undertaker, seemingly sensing the old man's unease, took a step back, his eyes never leaving his face. The silence between them was oppressive, heavy with unspoken words and unmet expectations. And then, just as suddenly as it had begun, the moment passed, and the old man turned and walked away, leaving the undertaker to his task. I was left standing there, wondering what I had just witnessed, and what it all meant. The hearse drove off, leaving me to ponder the old man's strange behavior. I couldn't shake the feeling that there was more to the story, that there was something hidden beneath the surface that I had yet to uncover. I lit a cigarette and took a long drag, trying to process what I had just seen. The old man's words kept echoing in my mind, "I didn't know whether the money was in there." What did he mean? Was he talking about something more than just the funeral? I didn't have any answers, but I was determined to find out. I started to follow the hearse, trying to get a glimpse of the old man's next move. As I walked, I couldn't help but wonder what other secrets lay hidden in this small town, secrets that only came to light in the most unexpected ways. The sun was setting, casting a golden glow over the streets, and I quickened my pace, eager to uncover the truth.

One of these was that doctor; another one was a sharp-looking gentleman, with a carpet-bag of the old-fashioned kind made out of carpet-stuff, that had just come off of the steamboat and was talking to him in a low voice, and
en_second_half: glancing towards the king now and then and nodding their heads—it was Levi Bell, the lawyer that was gone up to Louisville; and another one was a big rough husky that come along and listened to all the old gentleman said, and was listening to the king now. And when the king got done this husky up and says:
en_results_raw: The gentleman's voice was so low that it was almost a whisper, and the doctor's eyes were fixed intently on him as he spoke, while the others continued to laugh and chat, seemingly oblivious to the serious conversation taking place between the two men. The gentleman's words were laced with a hint of concern, and the doctor's expression turned grave as he listened, his brow furrowed in thought. The steamboat, which had brought the gentleman ashore, was now docked at the riverbank, its passengers disembarking and stretching their legs after the long journey. The sound of laughter and chatter filled the air, a stark contrast to the hushed tones of the conversation between the doctor and the mysterious gentleman. As the doctor nodded thoughtfully, the gentleman continued to speak, his words painting a picture of a situation that seemed to be growing more dire by the minute. The doctor's eyes darted towards the group of people still laughing and chatting, and for a moment, it seemed as though he was weighing his options, torn between his duty to help and his desire to keep the conversation private. But then, his expression hardened, and he turned back to the gentleman, his eyes locked intently on his face, as if to say that he was ready to listen, and to act, if necessary.

Uno de ellos era el médico, otro un caballero de aspecto astuto, con una bolsa de tela de esas anticuadas, hecha de tejido para alfombra, que acababa de desembarcar del barco de vapor y que hablaba con el médico en voz baja,
es_second_half: mientras miraban al rey de vez en cuando y hacían gestos con la cabeza: era Levi Bell, el abogado que había ido a Louisville, y otro era un tipo alto y robusto que se había acercado a oír lo que decía el anciano y que ahora escuchaba al rey. Y cuando terminó el rey, el tipo robusto va y dice:
es_results_raw: que parecía estar discutiendo sobre algo muy serio, mientras que el caballero astuto miraba hacia el grupo de personas que se reían con una expresión de disgusto en su rostro. El médico, por su parte, parecía estar intentando calmar a la multitud, explicándoles algo con un tono calmado y razonable, pero sin lograr convencer a nadie. En medio de este ambiente tenso, un hombre mayor, con una barba blanca y un sombrero de copa, se acercó al grupo y comenzó a hablar en voz alta, aclarando que la risa de la gente no era tan inocente como parecía, y que había algo más detrás de aquella risa, algo que no querían que nadie supiera. El médico se acercó a él y le pidió que se callara, pero el hombre mayor se negó, afirmando que alguien tenía que decir la verdad, y que él era ese alguien. La multitud se volvió hacia él, con una mezcla de curiosidad y miedo en sus ojos, y el hombre mayor continuó hablando, explicando que la risa de la gente no era solo una risa, sino que era una risa que ocultaba algo oscuro y peligroso, algo que amenazaba con destruir la comunidad entera. La gente comenzó a murmurar entre sí, y el médico se acercó a él, intentando calmarlo, pero el hombre mayor se negó a callarse, y continuó hablando, explicando que sabía lo que había detrás de aquella risa, y que estaba dispuesto a contar la verdad, incluso si eso significaba enfrentar a la multitud entera. La tensión en el aire era palpable, y la gente comenzaba a dividirse en dos grupos: aquellos que creían en la palabra del hombre mayor, y aquellos que se negaban a creer en él. El médico, por su parte, parecía estar intentando encontrar una solución, pero no sabía qué hacer, ya que la situación se estaba volviendo cada vez más complicada. El caballero astuto, por su parte, seguía mirando hacia el grupo con una expresión de disgusto, y parecía estar esperando a que algo sucediera. La situación se estaba volviendo cada vez más tensa, y nadie sabía qué iba a pasar a continuación.

es_first_half: Entre la cabaña y la valla, por el lado de atrás, había un cobertizo pegado a la cabaña por la parte del tejado y hecho de planchas de madera. Era igual de largo que la cabaña, pero estrecho: sólo unos seis metros de ancho. La puerta estaba del lado sur y tenía un candado. Tom fue al caldero del jabón y anduvo buscando, y volvió con esa cosa de hierro con que levantan la tapadera, así que hizo saltar una de las agarraderas del candado. Se
es_second_half: cayó la cadena, abrimos la puerta y entramos, la cerramos y al encender una cerilla vimos que el cobertizo sólo estaba construido junto a la cabaña, sin paso hacia ella, que no tenía un suelo, y no había nada más que unas cuantas azadas y palas oxidadas, unos picos y un arado roto. Se apagó la cerilla y nosotros nos fuimos y volvimos a poner la agarradera, de forma que la puerta quedó cerrada igual de bien que antes. Tom estaba encantado, y va y dice:
es_results_raw: abrió la puerta y entró en el cobertizo. Dentro, encontró una pila de herramientas y materiales de carpintería, junto con un viejo martillo, un destornillador y un cúter. También había una caja de herramientas con una llave inglesa y un destornillador de punta fina. Tom sacó la llave inglesa y la utilizó para abrir la caja, encontrando una serie de herramientas más especializadas, como un destornillador de punta larga y un alicate de pinza. Mientras examinaba las herramientas, se dio cuenta de que alguien había estado trabajando en el cobertizo recientemente, ya que había restos de cinta adhesiva y un trozo de papel con una nota escrita a mano. Tom la tomó y la leyó, pero no entendió el significado. La nota decía: "No toques nada. No digas nada. Espera a que llegue el momento". Tom se sintió confundido y un poco asustado. ¿Quién podría haber escrito esa nota y qué quería decir con ella? Se preguntó si debería seguir investigando o si debería regresar a la cabaña y olvidarse de todo. Pero su curiosidad lo llevó a seguir adelante, y decidió seguir investigando el cobertizo y sus secretos. Mientras tanto, el sol comenzaba a ponerse en el horizonte, y el cielo se volvía cada vez más oscuro. Tom sabía que debía encontrar respuestas antes de que la noche cayera, ya que no quería estar solo en la cabaña con la oscuridad. Se puso a buscar más pistas y a intentar descubrir el misterio del cobertizo, pero no sabía qué sorpresas le esperaban.

es_results_raw: trabajo en la tierra, que estaba llena de raíces y piedras, pero al menos habíamos logrado desenterrar un buen trozo de terreno. Después de eso, nos dimos cuenta de que necesitábamos un plan más sólido para seguir adelante, así que nos sentamos a pensar y a discutir qué podríamos hacer a continuación. Yo sugerí que necesitábamos una herramienta más adecuada para el trabajo, como una pico más larga o un azadón, y mi amigo estuvo de acuerdo. También propuso que deberíamos buscar ayuda adicional, ya que la tarea era demasiado grande para los dos solos. Así que decidimos ir a la aldea cercana a buscar a algunos más para que se unieran a nosotros. Mientras tanto, nos dimos cuenta de que el sol ya estaba empezando a ponerse, lo que nos dio una sensación de urgencia para terminar lo antes posible. Con la mente clara y un plan en marcha, nos pusimos a trabajar con más determinación que nunca, sabiendo que la noche no iba a ser fácil y que necesitaríamos estar listos para enfrentar cualquier obstáculo que se presentara.
tr_first_half: Bunun üzerine ben de bir kürek aldım, ondan sonra nöbetleşe kazmayı ve küreği kullanarak toprağı kazdık. Yarım saat daha çalıştık, ondan sonra uykusuzluğa dayanamaz olduk; ama artık epeyce büyük bir
tr_second_half: delik açmıştık. Merdivenlerden üst kata çıktım, pencereden baktığımda Tom’un canla başla paratonere tırmanmaya çalıştığını gördüm, ama bir türlü çıkamıyordu, çünkü avuçları kabarmıştı. “Hiç faydası yok, bunu yapmak mümkün değil,” dedi sonunda.
tr_results_raw: delik açmıştık. Toprağın derinlerine kadar kazdık, ama hâlâ bir şey bulamadık. Bu durum beni çok sinirlendiriyordu, çünkü bu toprakta bir antik kent kalıntısı olmalıydı. Uykusuzluğun etkisiyle kafamda bir plan oluşmaya başladı. Yarın sabah erkenden işe başlamak kararını verdim. Sabah erkenden kalkıp, kazı işlemini daha detaylı bir şekilde yapacağım. Belki de bu geceyi uykuyla geçireceğim, ama yarın sabaha karşı uyanıp, işimize gireceğim. Bu antik kent kalıntısını bulmak için elimden gelen her şeyi yapacağım.

en_results_raw: and made my way to the kitchen, the darkness of the cellar still clinging to me like a damp shroud. The air was thick with the scent of damp earth and mold, and I could feel the coolness of the cellar seeping into my bones. I fumbled my way through the darkness, my hands outstretched in front of me like a blind man, until I reached the bottom step. There, I paused for a moment, listening to the silence that filled the house. The only sound was the creaking of the old wooden floorboards beneath my feet, and the faint hum of a fly buzzing somewhere in the distance. I took a deep breath, and began my ascent up the stairs, the slab of corn-pone and the hunk of butter safely in hand. As I climbed, the darkness began to recede, and I could see the faint glow of the moon shining through the windows above. I quickened my pace, my heart beating a little faster with anticipation. What was I going to find when I reached the top of the stairs? Was it something good, or something bad? I didn't know, but I was about to find out.
